newsitem.title: UK: IFC emerging market index up 0.6 pct at 314.63.
newsitem.headline: IFC emerging market index up 0.6 pct at 314.63.

text.p: The International Finance Corporation's composite index of emerging market equities, denominated in dollars IFC/IPRD, rose 0.6 percent to 314.63 at the start of trade on Friday.
Latin America rose 1.0 percent day-on-day to 581.97, Asia was up 0.4 percent at 261.21 and Europe, Middle East and Africa was up 0.2 percent at 150.05.
The IFC composite index began 1997 at 294.37 after making gains of 7.0 percent in 1996. It touched a high this year of 315.20 after the close of trade on January 27.
ING Barings' Global Emerging Market Index (BEMI), also denominated in dollars BFFO, was up 0.71 percent day-on-day at 170.25 at 1000 GMT.
It began 1997 at 159.57 after rising 8.9 percent over the course of 1996. It touched a high of 171.22 after the end of trading on January 20.
Morgan Stanley's dollar-denominated Emerging Markets Free index .CEMF=USD was down 0.72 percent at 504.680, calculated after the close of trade on Wednesday.
It began 1997 at 476.315 after gaining 3.9 percent over 1996. Its 1997 high of 508.674 was also reached on January 20.

All indices are capitalisation-weighted and are calculated daily. The IFC index measures returns on equities, liquid and accessible to foreign investors, from 26 emerging market countries. It is updated at 2300 GMT.
The BEMI index measures equity returns without dividends from some 21 emerging market countries, with the latest changes reported by 0900 GMT.
The MSCI Free measures equity returns without dividends from 26 emerging market nations. Changes are reported at 1300 GMT.
The J.P. Morgan emerging market bond index ELMI, its returns calculated in dollar terms, rose 0.12 percent to a new 1997 high of 126.07 by the start of trade on Friday.
It began 1997 at 124.83 after jumping 14.86 percent over 1996.
By region, Latin America was up 0.17 percent at 104.64, Asia rose 0.06 to 132.35 and East Europe was down 1.16 at 161.19.
